titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Archiquette Collection
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:15

did.unittitle: John Archiquette collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection chiefly consists of professional and personal papers of John Archiquette that document events and activities of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin, primarily between 1876-1919. It also contains materials collected by his heirs, 1866-1984. The personal papers include ledger volumes that Archiquette used as journals and letter books, which include brief and frequent entries related to community affairs and events, as well as to his personal life and family. The collection also includes records of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin kept by Joseph O. Powless and Archiquette, which principally document deaths in the community, 1817-1880, as well as the records of the vestry council of the Church of the Holy Apostles in Oneida, Wisconsin, kept by Peter Bread and Archiquette, 1881-1906.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from John Cato on the Walter McClintock Memorial Fund, 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The John Archiquette Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Archiquette Collection. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: John Archiquette (1847-1923)
bioghist.p: John Archiquette (1847-1923) was a prominent member of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin. He was a veteran of the American Civil War; a captain of the Oneida Indian police force; a vestryman and warden of the Church of the Holy Apostles in Oneida, Wisconsin; and a member of the Oneida National Brass Band.

bioghist.head: Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin
bioghist.p: The Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin is a sovereign nation comprised of Oneida Indians who relocated from central New York state to eastern Wisconsin in and around Green Bay from 1823 to 1841.

bioghist.head: Holy Apostles Episcopal Church in Oneida, Wisconsin
bioghist.p: The Holy Apostles Episcopal Church in Oneida, Wisconsin, is a mission congregation of the Episcopal Diocese of Fond du Lac founded in 1825. The church was originally named Hobart Episcopal Church for John Henry Hobart (1775-1830), the third Episcopal bishop of New York (1816-1830).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection chiefly consists of professional and personal papers of John Archiquette that document events and activities of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin, primarily between 1876-1919. It also contains materials collected by his heirs, 1866-1984. The personal papers include ledger volumes that Archiquette used as journals and letter books, which include brief and frequent entries related to community affairs and events, as well as to his personal life and family. The collection also includes records of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin kept by Joseph O. Powless and Archiquette, which principally document deaths in the community, 1817-1880, as well as the records of the vestry council of the Church of the Holy Apostles in Oneida, Wisconsin, kept by Peter Bread and Archiquette, 1881-1906.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Personal Papers, 1866-1984. II. Records of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin, 1817-1866. III. Records of the Church of the Holy Apostles, Oneida, Wisconsin, 1881-1905.

did.unittitle: Personal Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Diaries and Letter Books, Logs, Correspondence, Notes, and Collected Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of volumes kept by John Archiquette, as well as logs, correspondence, and materials collected by Archiquette and his heirs that document events and activities at the reservation of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin.

did.unittitle: Diaries and Letter Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Diaries and letter books kept in ledger books by Archiquette that document events and activities at the Oneida Nation of Wisconsin.

The first six volumes include manuscript transcriptions of his monthly reports to the Indian agent in his role as the head of the police force on the Indian reservation, 1876-1901. The monthly reports includes logs of life events, including births, marriages, and deaths, as well as descriptions of legal infractions on tribal land, such as cutting timber without a permit, and social transgressions, such as adultery. The volumes include transcriptions of other official and personal correspondence by Archiquette.

The last two volumes were kept by Archiquette during his retirement, 1906-1919, The volumes include logs of life events, as well as records of his daily activities and transcriptions of his personal correspondence. There is also a fragment from a volume, which documents his activities in September and October 1910, as well as his financial disbursements in March 1910.

did.unittitle: Volume
Volume

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a transcription of a letter from Hiram Price (1814-1901), Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to Ebenezer Stephens (born circa 1835), who administered the Green Bay Agency, 1879-1882. The letter outlines provisos of the Oneida Treaty of 1838 (7 Stat. 566, Feb. 3, 1838).
Includes a transcription of the rules and regulations of the United States Indian Police Service in July 1878.

Includes transcriptions of personal correspondence, including letters to his children, Joel B. Archiquette (1870-1905) and Belinda Archiquette (1872-1910) while they attended the Carlisle Indian Industrial School.

did.unittitle: Volume
Volume

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a manuscript map of a strip of land adjoining his property that Archiquette purchased from his neighbor Thomas John, Sr., in 1890-1892.

Records of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of records related to the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin kept by Joseph O. Powless (died 1868) and continued by John Archiquette. The records include a bound volume that documents deaths, 1817-1880, as well as information related to tribal finances, circa 1866

did.unittitle: Log of Deaths
Tribal Finances
Records of the Vestry Council of the Church of the Holy Apostles, Oneida, Wisconsin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of records for the vestry council of the Church of the Holy Apostles, Oneida, Wisconsin. The records include a volume of vestry council records, 1881-1906, as well as scattered meeting notes from 1882 and 1905.

did.unittitle: Vestry Council Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first portion of the volume consists of records and meeting notes for the vestry council kept by Peter Bread (born 1845), April 18, 1881, to March 28, 1888.
The second portion of the volume consists of a log of work by individuals for the church, including quarrying stone, building structures, and preparing meals, April 24, 1882, to March 29, 1888.
The third portion of the volume consists of scattered records and meeting notes for the vestry council kept by John Archiquette, June 23, 1890, to April 16, 1906.
